including, but not limited to, school athletic, band and school entertainment practice or events. The use of a radio, stereo, or other device that amplifies sound
on public parks or playgrounds is permissible as long as the sound generated does not disturb other users of the facilities.
(Ordinance 08-054 adopted 11/18/08; 2008 Code, sec. 8.07.006)
ARTICLE 8.08 JUNKED VEHICLES*
Sec. 8.08.001 Definitions
Whenever the following terms are used in this article, they shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them in this section:
Demolisher. Any person whose business is to convert a motor vehicle into processed or scrap metal, or otherwise to wreck or dismantle motor vehicles.
Junked vehicle.
(1) A vehicle that:
(A) Is self-propelled; and
(B) Is:
(i) Wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled, or discarded; or
(ii) A motor vehicle that displays an expired license plate or does not display a license plate; or
(iii) A motor vehicle that is inoperable and has remained inoperable for more than:
a. 24-hours, if the vehicle is on public property; or
b. Twenty (20) calendar days, if the vehicle is on private property.
c. Once notice is provided, the amount of hours or days listed above continues regardless of whether the vehicle is moved from the street
to private property, or from private property to the street. The time and days do not reset once moved and a second notice is not required.
d. An extension of ten (10) calendar days may be provided to remove the vehicle upon written request from the vehicle owner to the chief
of police or city manager. The owner must show proof that the vehicle is in the process of being removed, or an emergency situation that
precludes the vehicle from immediate removal. Only one (1) extension shall be provided, if approved, by the chief of police or city manager.
(2) For purposes of this article, “junked vehicle” includes a motor vehicle, aircraft, or watercraft. This article applies only to:
(A) A motor vehicle that displays an expired license plate or does not display a license plate, or is wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled, or
abandoned;
(B) An aircraft that does not have lawfully printed on the aircraft an unexpired federal aircraft identification number registered under Federal Aviation
Administration aircraft registration regulations in 14 C.F.R. part 47; or
(C) A watercraft that:
(i) Does not have lawfully on board an unexpired certificate of number and is wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled, or abandoned; and
(ii) Is not a watercraft described by section 31.055, Parks and Wildlife Code.
Person. Any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind.
(Ordinance 08-008 adopted 2/5/08; 2008 Code, sec. 8.08.001; Ordinance adopting 2017 Code; Ordinance 2018-2, sec. 1, adopted 2/6/18)
Sec. 8.08.002 Declaration of nuisance; exceptions
(a) A junked vehicle, including a part of a junked vehicle, that is visible at any time of the year from a public place or public right-of-way:
(1) Is detrimental to the safety and welfare of the public;
(2) Tends to reduce the value of private property;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 123/349
(3) Invites vandalism;
(4) Creates a fire hazard;
(5) Is an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and safety of minors;
(6) Produces urban blight adverse to the maintenance and continuing development of municipalities; and
(7) Is a public nuisance.
(b) The location or presence of any junked vehicle or junked vehicles on any lot, tract, parcel of land or portion thereof, occupied or unoccupied, improved or
unimproved, within the city shall be deemed a public nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to cause or maintain such public nuisance by wrecking,
dismantling, rendering inoperable, abandoning or discarding his or their vehicle or vehicles on the property of another or to suffer, permit or allow the same to be placed,
located, maintained or exist upon his or their own real property; provided that this section shall not apply to:
(1) A vehicle or part thereof which is completely enclosed within a building in a lawful manner where it is not visible from the street or other public or private
property;
(2) A vehicle or part thereof which is stored or parked in a lawful manner on private property in connection with the business of a licensed vehicle dealer,
except that wrecked or dismantled vehicles may only be stored at locations authorized by city permit at a location authorized by city zoning to store or repair
vehicles;
(3) Unlicensed, inoperable antique vehicle(s) stored on property, provided that the vehicle(s) and the outdoor storage areas are maintained in such a
manner that they do not constitute a health hazard and are entirely screened from the ordinary public view by means of a fence, rapidly growing trees,
shrubbery, or other appropriate means. The use of a car covering alone does not constitute screening;
(4) Car repair businesses may only store junk vehicles on their property while the vehicle is being actively worked upon. A business requesting to store a
junk vehicle for more than thirty (30) calendar days shall provide a letter in writing to the city detailing the junk vehicle information and the reason the vehicle
will be maintained at the location for more than thirty (30) calendar days. It will be within the chief of police's sole discretion to approve or deny the request,
giving the car repair business ten (10) calendar days to remove the vehicle, if denied; or
(5) Outside storage of junk vehicles at any business is prohibited unless allowed outright by this code of ordinances, or city council approves a special use
permit under the present zoning or approves an application for rezoning.
(Ordinance 08-008 adopted 2/5/08; 2008 Code, sec. 8.08.002; Ordinance adopting 2017 Code; Ordinance 2018-2, sec. 2, adopted 2/6/18)
Sec. 8.08.003 Abatement order
(a) Whenever such public nuisance exists in the city in violation hereof, the chief of police and/or his subordinates, who shall administer and enforce this article, shall
give not less than ten (10) calendar days' notice to the owner of the real property or the occupant, if any, of the premises whereon such public nuisance exists to abate or
remove the same, stating the nature of the public nuisance on private property and that it must be removed and abated within ten (10) calendar days. Such notice to be
mailed, by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the owner or the occupant of the private or public premises whereupon such public nuisance exists. If
the notice is returned undelivered by the United States post office, official action to abate said nuisance shall be continued to a date not less than ten (10) calendar days
from the date of such return.
(b) Whenever such public nuisance exists in the city in violation hereof, the chief of police and/or his subordinates shall have not less than a ten-day period to give
notice, such notice to be mailed, by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the owner or the occupant of the public premises or to the owner or the
occupant of the premises adjacent to the public right-of-way whereupon such public nuisance exists. If the notice is returned undelivered by the United States post office,
official action to abate said nuisance shall be continued to a date not less than ten (10) days from the date of such return.
(c) If, within ten (10) days after the receipt of notice from the chief of police and/or his subordinates, or his duly authorized agent, to abate the nuisance, as herein
provided, the owner or occupant of the premises shall give his written permission to the chief of police and/or his employees, or his duly authorized agent, for removal of
the junked vehicles from the premises, the giving of such permission shall be considered compliance with the provisions of this section.
(Ordinance 08-008 adopted 2/5/08; 2008 Code, sec. 8.08.003; Ordinance 2018-2, sec. 3, adopted 2/6/18)
Sec. 8.08.004 Removal by city; disposal of removed vehicles
(a) If such public nuisance is not abated by said owner or occupant after notice is given in accordance with this article, official action shall be taken by the city to abate
such nuisance. Junked vehicles or parts thereof may be disposed of by removal to a scrap yard, demolisher, or any suitable site operated by the city for processing as
scrap or salvage, which removal or process shall be considered in [compliance with] subsection (c) of this section. A junked vehicle disposed of to a demolisher in
accordance with this article must be transferred to such demolisher by a form acceptable to the state department of transportation. The transfer receipt must be listed on
the demolisher's inventory list and surrendered to the state department of transportation in lieu of the certificate of title.
(b) The chief of police, and/or his subordinates, of the city shall administer the removal of a vehicle or parts thereof from the property. Such junked vehicle may be
disposed of as detailed above, or may be sold at auction with other vehicles stored in the city's impound lot. Vehicles sold at auction shall meet all requirements as
detailed in article 12.06 impound lot.
(Ordinance 08-008 adopted 2/5/08; 2008 Code, sec. 8.08.004; Ordinance 2018-2, sec. 4, adopted 2/6/18)
Sec. 8.08.005 Enforcement; right of entry
The chief of police and/or his subordinates, or his agent, may enter upon private property for the purposes specified in this article to examine vehicles or parts thereof, to
obtain information as to the identity or vehicles and to remove or cause the removal of a vehicle or parts thereof declared to be a nuisance pursuant to this article. The
city council shall have the authority to issue all orders necessary to enforce this article. (Ordinance 08-008 adopted 2/5/08; 2008 Code, sec. 8.08.005)
Sec. 8.08.006 Immediate removal of vehicles obstructing traffic
Nothing in this article shall affect ordinances that permit immediate removal of a vehicle left on public property which constitutes an obstruction to traffic. (Ordinance 08-
008 adopted 2/5/08; 2008 Code, sec. 8.08.006)
ARTICLE 8.09 DRAINS AND DRAINAGE EASEMENTS
Sec. 8.09.001 Throwing trash or debris in drain or easement
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or place any trash, brush, cut grass or weeds, debris or physical matter of any kind in or on any natural or artificial drain,
drainage ditch, drainage easement, or stream, creek or channel whatever in the city, or to permit the introduction of any such material into any such drain. (1972 Code,
sec. 23.401; 2008 Code, sec. 8.09.001)
Sec. 8.09.002 Placing fence or other obstacle in drain or easement
It shall be unlawful for any person to build or place any fence of any kind, or any other structure or physical obstacle, in, on or across any drainage easement, or any
natural or artificial drain, or any stream, creek or channel in the city, or any part thereof, without special permission from the city council, evidenced by an ordinance duly
passed, and then only in strict accord with the terms of such permission, if any. (1972 Code, sec. 23.402; 2008 Code, sec. 8.09.002)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 124/349
Sec. 8.09.003 Duty to keep easement clean
It shall be unlawful for the owner or tenant of any property in the city which is traversed to any extent by an improved drainage easement to fail to keep such drainage
easement on his property clean and free of all trash, brush, cut grass, weeds, debris or other physical matter which is or could be an obstacle, to any extent, to the free
flow of drainage waters at all times, without regard to the origin thereof. (1972 Code, sec. 23.403; 2008 Code, sec. 8.09.003)
Sec. 8.09.004 Discharging sewage or other substance into drains
(a) Prohibited. No person, firm, corporation, association, or political subdivision shall in any way, either directly or indirectly, cause or allow any chemical, liquid,
effluent, sewage, or any other substance, whether the same shall be treated or untreated, to be discharged into or run along any natural or open drain within the limits of
this city, whether such natural or open drain be a running stream or not.
(b) Declaration of nuisance. The addition of any chemical, liquid, effluent, sewage, or any other substance, whether the same be treated or untreated, to any natural or
open drain shall prima facie constitute a public nuisance.
(c) Industrial uses or other activities resulting in discharge to drain.
(1) No person, firm, corporation, association, or political subdivision shall construct, maintain, or operate any structure, plant, or other thing which shall in
any way result in the discharge of any chemical, liquid, effluent, sewage, or any other substance into any natural or open drain that flows through the limits of
the city.
(2) The construction, maintenance, or operation of any structure, plant, or other thing by any person, firm, corporation, association, or political subdivision,
which results in the discharge of any chemical, liquid, effluent, sewage, or any other substance into any natural or open drain that flows through the limits of
the city, whether the same has commenced, or the commencement of which is imminent or impending, shall constitute a nuisance to the welfare of this city
and its people and residents.
(1972 Code, secs. 23.404–23.406; 2008 Code, sec. 8.09.004)
ARTICLE 8.10 RESIDENTIAL RENTAL REGISTRATION AND INSPECTION
Sec. 8.10.001 Purpose
The city recognizes the need for an organized inspection program for new and aging residential rental units in order to upgrade rental units to meet city and state safety,
health, fire and zoning codes and to provide a more efficient system for compelling both absentee and local landlords to correct violations and to maintain, in proper
condition, rental property within the city. The city recognizes that the most efficient system to provide for rental inspections is the creation of a program requiring the
registration of all residential rental units within the city so that orderly inspection schedules can be made by city officials. (Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09; 2008 Code,
sec. 8.10.001)
Sec. 8.10.002 Definitions
(a) Rental property. For the purpose of this article, rental property shall mean a single-family dwelling, two-family dwelling, multifamily dwelling, dormitory, boarding
house, lodging or any combination of any such dwelling unit as defined herein.
(b) Additional definitions. The following terms were adapted from chapter 15, zoning, and shall have the following meanings:
Boarding home for sheltered care. A group home for the sheltered care of persons with special needs, which in addition to providing food and shelter may also provide
some combination of personal care, social or counseling services, and transportation.
Boarding house. A dwelling containing a single dwelling unit and not more than ten (10) guest rooms or suites of rooms, where lodging is provided with or without meals,
for compensation for more than one (1) week.
Condominium. A single dwelling unit in a multiunit dwelling or structure, which is separately owned and which may be combined with an undivided interest in the
common areas and facilities of the property.
Cottage. An individual single-family dwelling unit, being less than 1,500 heated square feet, situated with other similar dwelling units on one platted lot, for the purpose of
rental or leasing, as part of a multiple-family retirement community.
Dwelling. A house or other structure in which a person or persons live; a residence; abode; habitation; an apartment or building, or group of buildings, occupied as a
place of residence.
Dwelling, garden house. A detached dwelling unit with kitchen and sleeping facilities, designed for occupancy as a residence.
Dwelling, manufactured home. A vehicle, other than a motor vehicle, greater than 320 square feet in gross floor area, designed with attached axles and wheels, which
may be used for permanent or semipermanent living space for humans, and which is designed to be drawn by a motor vehicle. The term shall not include any vehicle
meeting the above description which is used for an office, a classroom, a laboratory, processing, manufacturing, retail sales or other use; see “Building, temporary” [in
section 15.02.052 of the zoning regulations] for these definitions. Also see “Manufactured housing” [in section 15.02.052 of the zoning regulations].
Dwelling, multiple-family. A building or portion thereof designed for occupancy by three (3) or more families living independently, in structures containing three (3) or
more single-dwelling units in which they may or may not share common entrances and/or other spaces. Individual dwelling units may be owned as condominiums, or
offered for rent.
Dwelling, single-family. A detached dwelling unit with kitchen and sleeping facilities, designed for occupancy as a residence.
Dwelling, single-family medium density. A detached dwelling unit with kitchen and sleeping facilities. Designed for occupancy as a residence, with a minimum lot area of
6,000 square feet.
Dwelling, townhouse. A building that has single-family dwelling units erected in a row as a single building, on adjoining lots, each being separated from the adjoining unit
or units by a firewall along the dividing lot line and each such building being separated from any other building by space on all sides.
Dwelling, two-family or duplex. A building designed or arranged to be occupied as two (2) separate residences, the structure having only two (2) dwelling units.
Dwelling unit. Any building or portion thereof which contains living facilities, including provisions for sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation, as required by this article,
for not more than one (1) family, or a congregate residence for six (6) or less persons.
Group home. A dwelling for no more than six (6) legally unrelated, developmentally disabled persons and no more than two (2) supervisory personnel. Said persons and
personnel must live as a single housekeeping unit, for the primary purpose of providing shelter in a family-like atmosphere as part of the residential community, with onsite
medical treatment or therapy a secondary purpose. A group home must qualify as a family home under chapter 123 of the Texas Human Resources Code, the
Community Homes for Disabled Persons Locations Act.
Guest house. Any living space with or without kitchen facilities which is to be used for the housing of two (2) or less persons, attached or unattached to the primary
structure of the site, intended to be used as an accessory use to the primary structure and not for profit purposes.
Guest room. Any room or rooms used or intended to be used by a guest for sleeping purposes. Every 100 square feet of superficial floor area in a dormitory shall be
considered to be a guest room.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 125/349
Hotel. Any building containing six (6) or more guest rooms offering transient lodging accommodations to the general public and providing additional services, such as
restaurants, meeting rooms, entertainment, and recreational facilities, rented or leased on a daily, weekly, or semipermanent basis.
(Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.002)
Sec. 8.10.003 Registration
(a) Registration requirements. No person shall hereafter occupy, allow to be occupied or let any other person occupy any residential rental property within the city for
which a registration statement has not been properly made and filed with the development office. Registration shall be made on forms furnished by the city for
registration purposes and shall specifically require the following minimum information:
(1) The name, address and phone number of the property owner and/or the designated local property manager if the property owner lives outside the
metropolitan statistical area (MSA).
(2) The street address of the rental property.
(3) The number and types of units within the rental property (dwelling units or sleeping rooms).
(4) The maximum number of occupants permitted for each dwelling unit or sleeping room.
(5) The name, phone number and address of the person authorized to make or order made repairs or services for the property, if in violation of city or state
codes, if the person is different than the owner or local manager.
(b) Manner of registering. The registration must be made on or before October 1, 2009, and annually thereafter by the property owner or designated local property
manager, in the office of the building inspection department of the city.
(c) Transfer of property. Every new owner of rental property (whether as fee owner or contract purchaser) shall be required to furnish to the development department
the new owner's name, address and phone number and the name, address and phone number of the owner's designated local manager before taking possession of the
rental property. No registration fee shall be required of the new owner during the year in which possession takes place provided that the previous owner has paid all
registration fees and has complied with all requirements of this article and any notices from the city concerning violations of health, zoning, fire or safety codes of the city.
If any change in the type of occupancy as originally registered is contemplated by the new owner, a new registration statement will be required.
(Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.003)
Sec. 8.10.004 Inspection required
(a) All dwellings, boarding houses, condominiums, cottages, and/or group homes that rent to permanent residents and dormitories shall be inspected systematically
for compliance with this article and all other applicable laws.
(b) The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
(1) Dwellings, buildings, structures and uses owned and operated by any governmental agency;
(2) Dwellings, buildings, structures and uses licensed and inspected by the state;
(3) Hotels that do not rent to permanent residents;
(4) Where a nonresidential business or activity, or a state-licensed and inspected use, occupies a portion of a building and premises which would be
otherwise subject to this article, the provisions of this article shall be applicable to the residential and common or public areas of such building and premises.
(Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.004)
Sec. 8.10.005 Frequency of inspections
(a) Generally. All rental dwellings subject to this article shall be inspected at least once every two years or upon change of occupancy, except as provided herein.
(b) New buildings. Neither the common areas nor the dwelling or rooming units in structures newly constructed shall be further inspected after the completion and
issuance of a certificate of occupancy for a multifamily unit or completion and final inspection of a single-family structure for a period of ten years from the date of said
certificate or final inspection, respectively, unless a complaint is made thereof. Thereafter said areas and units shall be inspected in accordance with the requirements of
this section.
(c) Inspection of multifamily dwellings.
(1) Ten percent of the entire complex will be inspected each year. Of these, five percent will be occupied units and five percent will be vacant units.
(2) As a result of such inspection, a list of all violations found in each unit, if any, shall be maintained by the inspection department. For each additional unit
that fails due to a high risk item, one additional unit will be inspected. Any reinspection shall require an additional fee as established by resolution of the city
council. High risk reinspections shall be conducted within three business days.
(Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.005)
Sec. 8.10.006 Inspection report required
No person shall rent, let or allow occupancy of any dwelling subject to this article without having a valid, current approved inspection report. (Ordinance 09-031 adopted
7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.006)
Sec. 8.10.007 Inspection procedure
(a) If, upon completion of the biennial inspection, the premises are found to be in compliance with all applicable city codes and ordinances and the appropriate fee has
been paid, the city shall issue an inspection slip/report.
(b) If, upon completion of the inspection, the premises are found to be in violation of one or more provisions of applicable city codes and ordinances, the city shall
provide written notice of such violation and shall set a reinspection date before which such violation shall be corrected. If such violation has been corrected within that
period, the city shall issue an approved inspection report for the premises. If such violations have not been corrected within that period, the city shall not issue an
inspection report and may take any action necessary to enforce compliance with applicable city codes and ordinances. If such uncorrected violations do not pose an
immediate threat to the health, safety, and welfare of the occupants, the city manager or designee may authorize the occupancy of the premises for a period not to
exceed 90 days.
(Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.007)
Sec. 8.10.008 Request for inspection
The owner of any dwelling subject to this article may request inspections of said dwelling at any time after proper request and payment. (Ordinance 09-031 adopted
7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.008)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 126/349
Sec. 8.10.009 Inspection report to be furnished to tenant upon request
Upon the request of an existing or prospective tenant, the owner or the owner's agent shall produce the inspection approval report. (Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09;
2008 Code, sec. 8.10.009)
Sec. 8.10.010 Suspension or revocation of approved inspection report
If the city manager or designee, after a hearing before the city manager or designee, determines that any person has failed to comply with this article or any applicable
city code or ordinance, the city manager may suspend or revoke the inspection report held by that person. Such a hearing shall be held not less than seven calendar
days after notice of the time, place, and subject of the hearing has been sent to the certificate holder at the holder's last known address or business address. The city's
representative shall present evidence in support of the suspension or revocation, and the certificate holder shall be permitted to rebut such evidence and present any
other evidence that is, in the discretion of the hearing officer, relevant and material. Based upon the evidence presented at the hearing, the hearing officer shall issue a
written decision. The suspension or revocation of any certificate of occupancy shall not release or discharge the certificate holder from paying any fees due to the city,
nor shall such certificate holder be released from prosecution for violating any code or ordinance. (Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.010)
Sec. 8.10.011 Appeals
If a property owner wishes to appeal the decisions of this article they may do so to the board of adjustment as set forth in chapter 15, zoning. (Ordinance 09-031 adopted
7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.011)
Sec. 8.10.012 Maintenance of records
All records, files, and documents pertaining to this article shall be maintained by the community development department and made available to the public as allowed or
required by state law or city ordinance. (Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.012)
Sec. 8.10.013 Exemptions
The provisions of this article shall not apply to hospital units, nursing units or retirement home units licensed by the state located within the city, all of which shall be
specifically exempt from registration under this article. (Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.013)
Sec. 8.10.014 Fees
A fee schedule as set forth in the fee schedule in appendix A of this code as amended or revised by ordinance from time to time shall be charged for compliance with
this article. (Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.014; Ordinance adopting 2017 Code)
Sec. 8.10.015 Violations declared nuisance; injunction
Any violation of this article is hereby declared to be a nuisance. In addition to any other relief provided by this article, the city attorney may apply to a court of competent
jurisdiction for an injunction to prohibit the continuation of any violation of this article. Such application for relief may include seeking a temporary restraining order,
temporary injunction and permanent injunction. (Ordinance 09-031 adopted 7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.015)
Sec. 8.10.016 Other enforcement actions
Nothing in this article shall prevent the city from taking action under any of its city fire, housing, zoning or other health and safety codes for violations thereof to seek
injunctive relief or criminal prosecution of such violations in accordance with the terms and conditions of the particular ordinance or code under which the city would
proceed against the property owner, designated property manager or occupant of any residential rental dwelling unit covered by this article. (Ordinance 09-031 adopted
7/7/09; 2008 Code, sec. 8.10.016)
ARTICLE 8.11 ILLEGAL SMOKING PRODUCTS AND INGESTION DEVICES
Sec. 8.11.001 Purpose
The purpose of this article is to prohibit the use, possession, sale, ingestion or smoking of illegal smoking products and ingestion devices hereinafter defined within the
city limits. (Ordinance 10-050 adopted 12/7/10; 2008 Code, sec. 8.11.001)
Sec. 8.11.002 Definitions
The following words and phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings as set forth in this section:
Illegal smoking product. Any plant or other substance, whether described as tobacco, herbs, incense, spice, or any blend thereof, regardless of whether the substance is
marked [marketed] for the purpose of being smoked, which includes any one or more of the following substances or chemicals:
(1) Salvinorin A: Contained within the Salvia divinorum plant, whether growing or not; or possessed as an extract, compound, manufacture, derivative,
mixture, or preparation of such plant;
(2) 2-[(1R, 3S)-3-hydroxycyclohexyl]-5-(2-methyloctan-2-yl) phenol (also known as CP 47, 497) and homologues;
(3) 1-pentyl-3-(1-naphthoyl) indole (also known as JWH-018);
(4) Butyl-3-(1-naphthoyl) indole (also known as JWH-073); or
(5) Any products sold, distributed or possessed in the form of incense or herbal smoking blends under the names such as “K-2,” “K-2 Summit,” “K-2 Sex,”
“Genie,” “Spice,” “Dascents,” “Zohai,” “Sage,” “Pep Spice,” “Solar Flare,” “K-O Knockout 2,” “Spice Gold,” “Spice Diamond,” “Spice Cannabinoid,” “Yucatan
Fire,” “Fire N' Ice,” or “Salvia Divinorum,” or related products or chemicals which when ingested produce intoxicating effects similar to marijuana.
Ingestion device. Equipment, a product or material that is used or intended for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing an illegal smoking product into the
human body, including:
(1) A metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipe with or without a screen, permanent screen, hashish head, or punctured metal bowl;
(2) A water pipe;
(3) A carburetion tube or device;
(4) A smoking or carburetion mask;
(5) A chamber pipe;
(6) A carburetor pipe;
(7) An electric pipe;
(8) An air-driven pipe;
(9) A chillum;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 127/349
(10) A bong; or
(11) An ice pipe or chiller.
Person. An individual, corporation, partnership, wholesaler, retailer or any licensed or unlicensed business.
(Ordinance 10-050 adopted 12/7/10; 2008 Code, sec. 8.11.002)
Sec. 8.11.003 Offenses; penalty
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to use, possess, purchase, barter, give, publicly display, sell or offer for sale any illegal smoking product.
(b) It shall be unlawful for any person to use or possess an ingestion device with the intent to inject, ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into the human body an
illegal smoking product.
(c) The culpable mental state required by section 6.02 of the Texas Penal Code, as amended, is specifically negated and dispensed with and a violation is a strict
liability offense.
(d) Any person, firm or corporation found to be violating any term or provision of this article shall be subject to a fine in accordance with section 1.01.009 of this code,
or the maximum amount allowed by law, for each offense. Every day a violation continues shall constitute a specific offense.
(Ordinance 10-050 adopted 12/7/10; 2008 Code, sec. 8.11.003; Ordinance adopting 2017 Code)
Sec. 8.11.004 Defenses
(a) It shall be an affirmative defense for a person charged with an offense for possession or use of an illegal smoking product that the use or possession was pursuant
to the direction or prescription of a licensed physician or dentist authorized to direct or prescribe such act.
(b) It shall be a primary affirmative defense that the sale or possession by a person of Salvinorin A was in conjunction with ornamental landscaping and used solely for
that purpose.
(Ordinance 10-050 adopted 12/7/10; 2008 Code, sec. 8.11.004)
ARTICLE 8.12 PARKS AND RECREATIONAL AREA SAFETY ZONES
Sec. 8.12.001 Definitions
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a
different meaning:
City. The City of Leon Valley, Texas.
City parks and recreational areas. Any land, including improvements to the land, which is administered, operated or managed by the city for the use of the general public
as a park, trail or natural area, and city recreational areas which include, but are not limited to: conservation areas, jogging trails, hiking trails, bicycle trails, stretches of
river designated for canoeing or kayaking, recreational centers, water parks, swimming pools, libraries, conference center, community center, soccer fields and baseball
fields. A map depicting the city parks shall be kept and maintained by the city's police department.
City park and recreational area safety zone. In the context of this article shall include, but not be limited to, Raymond Rimkus, the Nature Area, the Silo Park, Old Mill
Park, Hike and Bike Trail, Leon Valley Library, Leon Valley Community Center, Leon Valley Conference Center, Northwest Little League, Forest Oaks Pool, and the Leon
Valley Pool. It shall also include baseball and soccer fields, all city libraries, the Leon Valley Community Center, the Leon Valley Conference Center, and any park or
recreational areas to be added in the city in the future.
Loiter. Standing or sitting idly, whether in a vehicle or not, in and around an area.
Permanent residence. A place where the person abides, lodges, or resides for seven (7) or more consecutive days.
Sex offender. An individual who is required or has been required to register as a sex offender under chapter 62 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, or by a state or
federal agency. Sex offender shall also refer to civilly committed sexually violent predators, as referenced under V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code chapter 841.
Temporary residence. A place where a person abides, lodges or resides for a period of less than seven (7) total days during any calendar year and which is not the
person's permanent address, or a place where the person routinely abides, lodges or resides for a period of four (4) or more consecutive or nonconsecutive days in any
month and which is not the person's permanent address.
(Ordinance 2018-27 adopted 3/20/18)
Sec. 8.12.002 Sex offender residence restrictions
(a) It is an offense for a sex offender to establish a permanent or temporary residence within one thousand (1,000) feet of the real property comprising a city park and
recreational area safety zone.
(b) The residence restriction of this section applies to a home, apartment, motel, hotel group home, and internet rentals that are in the city park and recreational area
safety zone as defined in this article.
(c) A culpable mental state is not required for the commission of this offense and need not be proved.
(Ordinance 2018-27 adopted 3/20/18)
Sec. 8.12.003 Sex offender entry and loitering restrictions
(a) It is an offense for a sex offender to enter a city park and recreational area safety zone.
(b) It is an offense for a sex offender to loiter within five hundred (500) feet of a city park and recreational area safety zone.
(c) A person who is or has been subject to chapter 62 of the Code of Criminal Procedure who on at least three occasions during any month spends more than 48
consecutive hours in the city, and is not registered in our city, before the last day of that month shall report that fact to:
(1) The city police department;
(2) A person described by subsection (c) shall provide the city police department with all information the person is required to provide under article
62.051(c) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, to include the following:
(A) The address of any location in the city, as appropriate, at which the person was lodged during the month; and
(B) A statement as to whether the person intends to return to the city during the succeeding month.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 128/349
(d) A sex offender who has a right to be present at an official meeting is exempted from this section and may approach and enter a city park and recreational area
safety zone for such time as is necessary to attend the official meeting. This exemption shall only apply to those areas of the city park and recreational area safety zone
that are necessary for attendance at the official meeting, and any sex offender found outside such areas shall be in violation of this article. The sex offender shall be
required to contact the city police department at least 24 hours in advance and request an escort to the meeting.
(e) When a polling place for an election is located within a city park and recreational area safety zone, a sex offender is exempted from this section and may approach
and enter the city park and recreational area safety zone for the limited purpose of voting if the sex offender qualifies to vote at such place. This exemption shall only
apply to those areas of the city park and recreational area safety zone that are necessary for voting, and any sex offender found outside such areas shall be in violation
of this article. The sex offender shall be required to contact the city police department at least 24 hours in advance and request an escort to the meeting.
(Ordinance 2018-27 adopted 3/20/18)
Sec. 8.12.004 Distance measurement
Distances under this article shall be measured between the sex offender's residence, temporary residence or location and the nearest property line of the city park and
recreational area safety zone. (Ordinance 2018-27 adopted 3/20/18)
Sec. 8.12.005 Affirmative defenses
(a) It is an affirmative defense to prosecution for sex offender residence restrictions that the sex offender had already established a temporary or permanent residence
within the city park and recreational area safety zone prior to the date of this article's adoption, and has complied with all of the sex offender registration laws of the state.
(b) It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this article that the sex offender was a minor when the offense was committed, and does not qualify as a sex
offender under this article as an adult.
(c) It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this article that the sex offender is under an order of a court in the state or of the Texas Department of Criminal
Justice Parole Board, permitting the person to be within the city park and recreational area safety zone.
(Ordinance 2018-27 adopted 3/20/18)
Sec. 8.12.006 Exemptions
(a) Exemptions from the terms of this article shall not be contrary to the public interest but may be granted where, owing to special conditions, or when a literal
enforcement of the provisions of this article will result in unnecessary hardship.
(b) A sex offender shall have the right to make an appeal for an exemption from a provision of this chapter by making a request to the chief of the police department,
in writing, stating why an exemption should be granted.
(c) The decision of the chief of police, which may be made based solely on the written appeal without further hearing, shall be final.
(Ordinance 2018-27 adopted 3/20/18)
Sec. 8.12.007 Penalties
(a) Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a class C misdemeanor and upon adjudication or conviction thereof shall be fined in
an amount not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each and every offense.
(b) Each and every violation or day such violation shall continue or exist shall be deemed a separate offense.
(c) The penal provisions imposed under this section shall not preclude the city from filing suit to enjoin a violation of this section.
(d) The city shall retain all legal rights and remedies available to it pursuant to local, state and federal law.
(Ordinance 2018-27 adopted 3/20/18)
CHAPTER 9
PERSONNEL
ARTICLE 9.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS
Sec. 9.01.001 Continuation of social security payments for city employees
(a) The agreement with the Social Security Administration shall be amended to be consistent with the current policy of providing for social security payments for all
paid employees.
(b) Staff is to hereby notify the Social Security Administration accordingly of this action taken by the city council.
(Ordinance 05-044 adopted 12/6/05; 2008 Code, sec. 9.01.001)
State law reference–Social security, V.T.C.A., Government Code, ch. 606.
Sec. 9.01.002 Substance abuse policy; drug and alcohol testing
(a) Substance abuse policy adopted. The city council does hereby adopt comprehensive substance abuse policies and detection methods to ensure, as fully as
possible, to the citizens of the city, public servants who shall be free from such abusive practices. A copy of these policies is attached to Ordinance 1348 as the
Substance Abuse Policy.
(b) Drug and alcohol testing.
(1) Any public servant may be subject to a fitness for duty examination when reasonable suspicion exists either that the employee is currently under the
influence of drugs or alcohol or that the employee's behavior, over a period of time, indicates substance abuse, further providing for search of an employee's
personal property when there is reasonable suspicion that the employee is in possession of drugs or alcohol, either on city property or while conducting city
business. Any employee refusing to submit to a fitness for duty examination, or refusing to sign a fitness for duty examination consent form, will be subject to
dismissal. All prospective employees and appointed members of city positions shall be refused consideration for such employment or appointment if they test
positive from such screening.
(2) The city manager will establish policies/procedures which comply with the federal government Department of Transportation regulations requiring drug
and alcohol testing for employees who operate vehicles which require a commercial driver's license.

ARTICLE 9.02 POLICE*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 9.02.001 City marshal service abolished; officers reassigned to police department
(a) Ordinance No. 04-001 that allowed for the creation of the city marshal service is repealed.
(b) The police officers assigned to the city marshal service will be reassigned as police officers to the city police department.
(c) The appointment of and the powers of these police officers will be as provided for in this article.
(Ordinance 06-042 adopted 10/3/06; 2008 Code, sec. 9.03.001)
State law reference–Abolition of office of marshal, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 22.076.
Secs. 9.02.002–9.02.030 Reserved
Division 2. Police Department
Sec. 9.02.031 Creation
There is hereby created the city police department, which shall be operated as a departmental function of the city. (Ordinance 06-043 adopted 10/3/06; 2008 Code, sec.
9.03.002)
Sec. 9.02.032 Chief of police and other positions
The position of chief of police is hereby created. The chief of police shall be the executive head of such department. The city council shall create such additional
positions in the police department as it shall deem advisable from time to time. The city manager will be the appointing and removing authority for all positions within the
police department, with the exception of the chief of police, whose appointment or removal must be confirmed by the city council. (Ordinance 06-043 adopted 10/3/06;
2008 Code, sec. 9.03.003)
Sec. 9.02.033 Powers of police officers
The police officers appointed pursuant hereto shall have all of the powers, rights and authorities vested in police officers and conferred by Texas Local Government
Code, chapter 341, Municipal Law Enforcement, as well as those conferred by articles 2.12 and 2.13 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, or as otherwise provided by
state law. (Ordinance 06-043 adopted 10/3/06; 2008 Code, sec. 9.03.004)
Sec. 9.02.034 Emergency interlocal assistance
The mayor or other authorized official, when requested for assistance under the provisions of Local Government Code 362.002, Law Enforcement Assistance, is hereby
authorized to send members of the police department to assist in police duties of the requesting municipality or county during a state of civil emergency as defined in
said statute. (Ordinance 06-043 adopted 10/3/06; 2008 Code, sec. 9.03.006)
State law reference–Law enforcement services provided through cooperation of municipalities, counties and certain other local governments, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec.
362.001 et seq.
Sec. 9.02.035 Arrest without warrant
Pursuant to article 14.03 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, officers of the police department are authorized to arrest, without warrant, persons found in
suspicious places, and under circumstances which reasonably show that such persons have been guilty of some felony or breach of the peace, or threaten or are about
to commit some offense against the laws. (1972 Code, sec. 1.1001; 2008 Code, sec. 9.03.007)
State law reference–Authority to make arrest without warrant, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. sec. 14.01 et seq.
Secs. 9.02.036–9.02.070 Reserved
Division 3. Police Reserve Force*
Sec. 9.02.071 Appointment of members; powers
There is hereby created the position of reserve police officer. The chief of police shall appoint members of the reserve police force. The reserve police officers appointed
pursuant hereto shall have all of the powers, rights and authorities vested in police officers and conferred by Texas Local Government Code, chapter 341.102, Reserve
Police Force, as well as those conferred by articles 2.12 and 2.13 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, or as otherwise provided by state law. (Ordinance 06-043 adopted
10/3/06; 2008 Code, sec. 9.03.005)
