ARTICLE 14.07 UTILITY EASEMENTS
Sec. 14.07.001 Fencing
(a) The owner of property upon which a utility easement is located may use it for lawn purposes, and in such cases fencing across the easement shall be permitted.
However, gates along the side lot lines must be provided. The gates shall be fifteen feet (15') wide (two 7-1/2 foot gates) and shall be capable of being opened and
closed at all times. These gates shall be secured in the center by a drop rod or some similar device which does not obstruct free passage over the easement. The drop
rod may be lowered into a drop rod keeper, installed so as to be flush with the ground level. No permanent type center pole for the gates may be erected on the
easement.
(b) The gates provided for herein shall remain unlocked at all times. Post and chain gates as specified herein shall be installed at the ends of the utility easements and
shall be capable of being opened, closed and locked at all times.
(1972 Code, sec. 14.501; 2008 Code, sec. 13.07.001)
Sec. 14.07.002 Maintenance; obstructions
Maintenance of the easement shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property upon which it is located. It shall be the duty of the property owner to keep the area
across, over or under this easement clear of any structure, debris, vegetation, trees, shrubs or landscaping whatsoever, except that lawn grass, which shall be regularly
mowed and controlled, may be grown thereon. No boats, automobiles, trailers, garbage cans, boxes or obstacles to the free movement of vehicular traffic whatsoever
shall be placed, parked, or permitted to remain in such easements. (1972 Code, sec. 14.502; 2008 Code, sec. 13.07.002)
ARTICLE 14.08 UTILITY CONSTRUCTION PERMIT*
Sec. 14.08.001 Required; issuance
(a) Applicability. Except as provided for herein, every individual, company, corporation, municipal corporation, utility district or other entity wishing to install, repair,
replace or maintain a utility line within the city where installation, repair, replacement or maintenance involves underground excavation must first secure a utility
construction permit from the city. Underground work permits are required within utility easements on private property. Except as may be required by other sections of the
city's ordinances, permits are not required for underground work on private property outside of utility easements.
(b) Franchise holders.
(1) Utility operators franchised by the city and their subcontractors must:
(A) Obtain a utility construction permit prior to beginning work. Permits shall not be issued until completion of the following:
(i) Permit application/construction plans. A permit request showing location, type of work to be performed, and other relevant information
requested by the city shall be submitted to the city development office along with three (3) copies of the utility construction plans;
(ii) Permit review. The director of public works or his designated representative shall review all documents submitted and make
recommendations;
(iii) Payment of all fees. Franchise holders are exempt from permit fees; and
(iv) Procedure. The city development office shall review the comments of the department of public works and thereafter approve or deny the
permit.
(B) Comply with the general conditions of the city for utility construction and special conditions indicated on the permit.
(C) If work is in a paved area, comply with section 14.08.003 and the general conditions of the city for utility construction.
(2) In emergency situations, franchise holders may begin work following the general conditions of the city for utility construction without first obtaining a
permit; however, a permit must be applied for the following business day. An emergency situation is considered a condition which is unsafe or where service
to customers will be interrupted unless immediate action is taken.
(3) Some franchise holders are contractually exempt from portions of this section.
(c) Non-franchise holders. Utility operators not holding a franchise with the city and their subcontractors shall comply with the provisions of subsection (b) of this
section and pay the following: Permit fees of ten percent (10%) of the city-approved estimate of project cost/valuation and not less than an amount as provided in
appendix A of this code as amended or revised by ordinance from time to time must be paid to the city.
(Ordinance 97-037 adopted 11/4/97; Ordinance adopting 2008 Code; 2008 Code, sec. 13.08.001; Ordinance adopting 2017 Code)
Sec. 14.08.002 Approval of plans
A permit will be issued by the city secretary for utility construction only after the plans have been approved by the city engineer. Scaled drawings showing the proposed
work and the relation to existing facilities are required. Additional information may be required by the city engineer. Such drawings shall bear the seal of an engineer
registered to practice engineering in the state and shall be submitted to the city engineer in the number of copies required by him. (Ordinance 443 adopted 4/18/72; 2008
Code, sec. 13.08.002)
Sec. 14.08.003 Work in paved areas
(a) Where work involves the underground crossing of paved areas, the city will require the applicant to install their line within a conduit by boring under the paved
areas.
(b) In the alternative and at the city's sole option, the city may, in some instances, allow the applicant to open-cut paved areas. If such permission is granted, the
following conditions must be met:
(1) Prepayment to the city of a predetermined amount per linear foot of the street cut. This cost shall reflect the actual cost to the city for materials and
contract labor used for street overlay;
(2) As necessary, the city may change, alter or impose other requirements to protect the interest of the city;
(3) Compliance with section 14.08.001.
(Ordinance 97-037 adopted 11/4/97; 2008 Code, sec. 13.08.003)
Sec. 14.08.004 Bond
(a) All contractors doing work requiring the cutting of an existing street or easement under this article shall post a maintenance bond in an amount sufficient to
guarantee repair of the right-of-way or easement should the contractor not do so properly. The engineer preparing the plans shall also prepare an estimate for such work
for approval by the city engineer.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 208/349
(b) The maintenance bond so submitted for shall guarantee the work performed for a 6-month period, from the date of acceptance by the city, against failure due to
workmanship or materials.
(c) Such bond as required above is a prerequisite of the issuance of any permit under this article.
(d) The contractor shall notify the city secretary one day in advance of beginning any work and shall again notify the city secretary upon completion of the work for a
final inspection. The contractor shall allow 24 hours minimum time for a final inspection by the city.
(Ordinance 443 adopted 4/18/72; 2008 Code, sec. 13.08.004)
Sec. 14.08.005 Safety requirements
During construction, the contractor shall conform to all code provisions governing safety and shall provide adequate detours and flagmen if required to insure the safety
of the public. (Ordinance 443 adopted 4/18/72; 2008 Code, sec. 13.08.005)
ARTICLE 14.09 STORMWATER MANAGEMENT UTILITY*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 14.09.001 Definitions
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings indicated:
Assessment roll. The official listing of assessments of real property maintained by the Bexar County Appraisal District.
Base rate. The stormwater management fee charged on a square foot of benefited real property.
Benefited property. An improved lot or tract to which drainage service is made available under this article.
Board. The stormwater management board for the city. The city council is designated as the stormwater management board.
Certificate of occupancy. The final inspection by the city building inspector.
City manager. The city manager for the City of Leon Valley.
Commercial property. All developed property not meeting the definition of residential property, multifamily property or public property.
Cost of service. As applied to a drainage system service to any benefited property:
(1) The prorated cost of the acquisition, whether by eminent domain or otherwise, of land, rights-of-way, options to purchase land, easements, and
interests in land relating to structures, equipment, and facilities used in draining the benefited property;
(2) The prorated cost of the acquisition, construction, repair, and maintenance of structures, equipment, and facilities used in draining the benefited
property;
(3) The prorated cost of architectural, engineering, legal, and related services, plans and specifications, studies, surveys, estimates of cost and of revenue,
and all other expenses necessary or incident to planning, providing, or determining the feasibility and practicability of structures, equipment, and facilities
used in draining the benefited property;
(4) The prorated cost of all machinery, equipment, furniture, and facilities necessary or incident to the provision and operation of draining the benefited
property;
(5) The prorated cost of funding and financing charges and interest arising from construction projects and the start-up cost of a drainage facility used in
draining the benefited property;
(6) The prorated cost of debt service and reserve requirements of structures, equipment, and facilities provided by revenue bonds or other drainage
revenue-pledged securities or obligations issued by the municipality.
Council. The city council of the City of Leon Valley.
Developed property. Real property which has been altered from its natural condition by the addition of any improvements such as buildings, structures, or other
impervious area.
Drainage. Bridges, catchbasins, channels, conduits, creeks, culverts, detention ponds, ditches, draws, flumes, pipes, pumps, sloughs, treatment works, and
appurtenances to those items, whether natural or artificial, or using force or gravity, that are used to draw off surface water from land, carry the water away, collect, store,
or treat the water, or divert the water into natural or artificial watercourses, and shall be used synonymously with “stormwater.”
Fee. The monthly service stormwater management charge established under this article and levied on owners of benefited real property to fund the costs of stormwater
management, including operating, maintaining, and improving the stormwater system in the city.
Fund. The stormwater management fund created by this article to operate, maintain, and improve the city's stormwater system.
Impervious surface. The number of square feet of surface area covered by buildings or other improvements which are compacted or covered with material that is
resistant to infiltration by water, including, but not limited to, most conventionally surfaced streets, roofs, sidewalks, patios, driveways, parking lots, and any other oiled,
graveled, graded, or any other surface which impedes the natural infiltration of surface water as determined by the city.
Multifamily property. A developed property which serves the primary purpose of providing three (3) or more permanent dwelling units.
Nonpoint source pollution. Pollutants which are not otherwise permitted for discharge, including but not limited to soil erosion, motor oils, antifreeze, gasoline, fertilizers,
pesticides, household chemicals, faulty septic systems, and animal wastes.
Pollution. The alteration of the physical, thermal, chemical, or biological quality of, or the contamination of, any water of the state or water of the United States, that
renders the water harmful, detrimental, or injurious to humans, animal life, vegetation, or property, or to the public health, safety, or welfare, or impairs the usefulness or
the public enjoyment of the water for any lawful or reasonable purpose.
Property owner. The property owner of record as listed in the assessment roll. A property owner includes any individual, corporation, firm, partnership, or group of
individuals acting as a unit, and any trustee, receiver, or personal representative.
Public property. A developed property which serves the primary purpose for use by the public such as, but not limited to, a church or a school.
Residential property. A developed property which serves the primary purpose of providing a permanent dwelling unit and which is classified as residential in the
assessment roll. A single-family detached dwelling, townhouse or a second dwelling unit (duplex) is included in this definition.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 209/349
Stormwater. Surface flow water from precipitation that accumulates in and flows through natural and/or man-made storage and conveyance systems during and
immediately following a storm event.
Stormwater management. The planning, design, construction, regulation, enforcement, improvement, repair, maintenance, and operation of facilities and programs
relating to water, pollutants, grading, erosion, tree conservation, and sediment control.
Stormwater system. The system or network of stormwater management facilities, including but not limited to inlets, conduits, manholes, channels, ditches, drainage
easements, retention and detention basins and other components as well as all natural waterways within the city.
Undeveloped property. Any property that is in its natural condition.
User. The person or entity who owns or occupies a benefited property.
Water. Any stormwater, surface water, snowmelt or groundwater.
(Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.001)
Sec. 14.09.002 Statutory powers
The statutory powers as to public utilities granted by Vernon's Annotated Revised Civil Statutes of Texas, title 28, Cities, Towns and Villages, chapter 10, Public Utilities,
articles 1106 through 1132, inclusive, and the Environmental Protection Agency and the state commission on environmental quality, and other powers as adopted by this
article, are hereby recognized and expressly declared to embody the policy and power of the city with respect to public utilities. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted
1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.002)
Sec. 14.09.003 Responsibility for stormwater management
The city is responsible for stormwater management in the city. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.003)
Sec. 14.09.004 Authority
The governing body of a municipality is authorized by the Texas Local Government Code, sec. 552.045 adoption of system; rules, to adopt a system of charges to fund
the implementation of stormwater and drainage management programs. This section declares the drainage system of the municipality to be a public utility. (Ordinance
09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.004; Ordinance 2018-71 adopted 9/4/18)
Sec. 14.09.005 Enactment
The city is enacting a stormwater management fee system based on factors that influence runoff, including the size of the parcel, the pollutants present, and the land
use of the property. The governing body must publish a notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the municipality stating the time and place of a public hearing to
consider the proposed ordinance. The proposed ordinance must be published in full in the notice. The governing body shall publish the notice three times before the
date of the hearing. The first publication must occur on or before the 30th day before the date of the hearing. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code,
sec. 13.09.005)
Sec. 14.09.006 Administration
The municipality must hold a public hearing on the charges before levying the charges. The municipality must give notice of the hearing in the manner provided by
section 14.09.005. The proposed schedule of drainage charges as originally adopted, or as revised, must be published in the notice. After completion of the public
hearing on the charges, the municipality may levy a schedule of drainage charges. The schedule of drainage charges must be based on an inventory of lots and land in
the service area. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.006)
Sec. 14.09.007 Scope of utility
All real property in the city, including property owned by public and tax-exempt entities, contributes to runoff and pollution of the receiving stream and either uses or
benefits from the stormwater system. State law requires a municipality to set customer fees on any basis other than the value of the property. Fees are to be directly
related to drainage, and drainage services must be afforded on a nondiscriminatory, equitable, and reasonable basis. Equity for all ratepayers is the primary objective in
establishing a drainage utility - each customer pays a fee relative to the amount of stormwater runoff service or damage generated from a property, negatively affecting
the public health and safety in loss of the life and property as a result of surface water overflows, surface water stagnation, and pollution arising from nonpoint source
runoff within the boundaries of the established service area. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.007)
Sec. 14.09.008 Causes
Stormwater runoff results in overflow damage, stagnation and associated health hazards, and contributes to nonpoint source pollution of the drainage systems of the
city, and a stormwater management program is required to reduce this type of damage, including pollution. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec.
13.09.008)
Sec. 14.09.009 Fee system
It is in the interests of the public to fund stormwater management with a user fee system that allocates the costs of stormwater management to benefited property
owners in the city. A stormwater management fee system offers additional financial management options that would assist the city to improve stormwater services. After
a determination of the utility revenue requirements and the selected billing rate structure, a schedule of charges will be developed for the new utility. The standard billing
rate will be calculated by dividing the necessary revenue requirement by the total number of billing units in the customer database. The initial rate will be designed with
adequate revenue generation to cover the annual revenue requirements for subsequent years. This allows for a constant utility rate for the first four years of utility
operation. The council may make changes to the rate system as allowed by law and may give additional notification to citizens of required hearings, whether one or
more, through the stormwater management fee billing at least 30 days prior to a public hearing. The date of the public hearing will be posted as provided by law and
provided on the billing notice. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.009)
Sec. 14.09.010 Stormwater drainage revenue bonds
As provided in Local Government Code, section 552.051, and Government Code, title 9, chapter 1201, by majority vote of the council, the city may issue stormwater
drainage revenue bonds. The city may use the Bond Procedures Act of 1981 (article 717k-6, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes) [Public Security Procedures Act, V.T.C.A.,
Government Code, chapter 1201]. In addition, the city may pledge income received by contracts for the provision of stormwater drainage services to other governments
or governmental subdivisions located inside or outside the service area. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.010; Ordinance 2018-71
adopted 9/4/18)
Sec. 14.09.011 Enforcement
Unless the property is exempted, a person must pay the established fee to the drainage system. Failure to pay such charges will subject such person to legal actions set
forth below. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.011)
Sec. 14.09.012 Segregation of income
The income of a drainage utility system must be segregated and completely identifiable in municipal accounts. If drainage charges are solely for the cost of service, the
municipality may transfer the charges in whole or in part to the municipal general fund, except for any part collected outside municipal boundaries and except for any
part pledged to retire any outstanding indebtedness or obligation incurred, or as a reserve for future construction, repair, or maintenance of the drainage system. If the
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 210/349
governing body has levied, in the drainage charge, an amount in contribution to the funding of future system improvements, including replacement, new construction, or
extension, that amount is not transferable to the general fund. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.012)
Secs. 14.09.013–14.09.050 Reserved
Division 2. Funding
Sec. 14.09.051 Findings
(a) The city owns, operates and maintains a stormwater system.
(b) The stormwater system in the city needs regular maintenance and improvements.
(c) Water quality is degraded by erosion and the discharge of nutrients, metals, oil, grease, toxic materials, and other substances introduced into and through the
stormwater system.
(d) The public health, safety, and welfare are adversely affected by degraded water quality that results from stormwater.
(e) All real property in the city either uses or benefits from the maintenance and improvement of the stormwater system.
(f) The extent of use of the stormwater system by each property is dependent on factors that influence runoff, including land use and the amount of impervious surface
on the property.
(g) The costs of improving, maintaining, operating, and monitoring the stormwater system should be allocated, to the extent practicable, to all benefited property
based on the impact of stormwater runoff from the property into the stormwater management system.
(h) Management of the stormwater system to protect the public health, safety, and welfare requires adequate revenues and it is in the interest of the public to finance
stormwater management adequately with a user charge system that is “reasonable and equitable” so that each user of the system pays to the extent to which he
contributes to the need for it.
(Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.051)
Sec. 14.09.052 Stormwater management fund established
(a) The stormwater management program is established and the stormwater system is provided to protect the waterways and land in the city by protecting the natural
environment. The costs of designing, developing, improving, operating, maintaining, and monitoring the stormwater system required in the city should, therefore, be
allocated, to the extent practicable, to all property owners based on their impact on the stormwater system. In order to provide revenue to fund those costs and to fairly
allocate those costs, a stormwater management fund is established.
(b) All revenues collected from the stormwater management fee, and from grants, permit fees, and other charges collected by stormwater management, shall be
deposited to the fund. The council may make additional appropriations to the fund. All disbursements from the fund shall be for the purposes of the fund as set forth in
section 14.09.053.
(Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.052; Ordinance 2018-71 adopted 9/4/18)
Sec. 14.09.053 Purposes of fund
The fund shall be used for the following purposes:
(1) All costs of administration and implementation of the stormwater management program, including the establishment of reasonable operating and capital
reserves and contingencies;
(2) Operation and maintenance of the stormwater system;
(3) Monitoring, surveillance, and inspection of stormwater devices;
(4) Water quality programs;
(5) Inspection and enforcement activities;
(6) Legal expenses;
(7) Billing and administrative costs; and
(8) Other activities that are reasonably required for the operation of the stormwater program.
(Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.053)
Sec. 14.09.054 Classification of property for purpose of determining fee
For purposes of determining the stormwater management fee, all properties in the city are classified into one of the following classes:
(1) Residential property;
(2) Commercial property;
(3) Multifamily property; or
(4) Public use property.
(Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.054)
Sec. 14.09.055 Fee established
A monthly service charge is imposed upon all benefited real property beginning January 1, 2009 to fund stormwater management programs. This service charge shall be
known as the stormwater management fee (“fee”). Any real property completed or added to the county tax assessment roll after January 1, 2009, or annexed into the
city after January 1, 2009, will be subject to the monthly charge. The fee is based on:
(1) The property land area in square feet;
(2) The classification of the property; and
(3) The cost of implementing, operating and maintaining a stormwater management program.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 211/349
(Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.055)
Sec. 14.09.056 Base rate
The board shall, as set forth in section 14.09.091, establish the effective unit rate for the stormwater management fee. The base rate shall be calculated to insure
adequate revenues to fund the costs of stormwater management and to provide for the operation, maintenance, and capital improvements of the stormwater system in
the city. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.056)
Sec. 14.09.057 Exemptions from fee
(a) The council finds that all benefited real property in the city contributes to runoff and either uses or benefits from the maintenance of the stormwater system.
Therefore, all real property in the city, excluding properties that are under city, school district, state, and federal ownership, shall be charged with a fee.
(b) Reserved.
(c) New residence development is exempt, until the city has completed final occupancy inspections.
(d) Property with proper construction and maintenance of a wholly sufficient and privately owned drainage system may reduce the fee to the extent that the private
drainage system is effective.
(e) Property held and maintained in its natural state is exempt, until such time that the property is developed.
(Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.057; Ordinance 2018-71 adopted 9/4/18)
Sec. 14.09.058 Payment of fee; delinquency; lien for overdue fees
(a) The monthly fee must be paid within 30 days after the bill is mailed or issued to the property owner and is overdue after that date. An overdue fee penalty will be
assessed at the rate specified in the rate ordinance.
(b) The fee, including interest and penalties, when overdue, constitutes the basis for the city filing a lien on real property and may be collected in the same manner as
a delinquent electric bill or by a suit against the property owner or other methods as allowed by law. During the period when the fee is overdue and after written notice to
the owner, the property is no longer authorized to deliver stormwater to the city's stormwater system.
(c) The city manager may abate the fee, including interest and penalties, if it is determined by the city to be in error or otherwise not collectable.
(Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.058)
Sec. 14.09.059 Request for correction of fee
(a) A property owner may request correction of the fee by submitting a written request to the city manager at 6400 El Verde Road, Leon Valley, Texas, 78238, within
30 days after the date the assessment notice or the bill is mailed or issued to the property owner. Grounds for correction of the fee include:
(1) Incorrect classification of the property for purposes of determining the fee;
(2) An error in the square footage of the property;
(3) Mathematical error in calculating the fee to be applied to the property; and
(4) Errors in the identification of the property owner of a property subject to the fee.
(b) Requests for correction of errors which are received after 30 days will be considered; however, no credit for any levy prior to receipt of the request shall be issued.
The city manager shall make a determination within 30 days after receipt of the property owner's completed written request for correction of the fee. The city manager's
decision on a request for correction of the fee shall end the administrative remedies available to the customer.
(c) A property owner must comply with all rules and procedures adopted by the city when submitting a request for correction of the fee and must provide all
information necessary for the city manager to make a determination on a request for correction of the fee. If a property owner alleges an error under section 14.09.091,
the request for correction must include a certification by a registered engineer or professional land surveyor of the size in square feet of the property if the property is
unplatted. Failure to comply with the provisions of this subsection shall be grounds for denial of the request.
(Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.059)
Sec. 14.09.060 Discontinuation of drainage system
(a) If, after at least five years of substantially continuous operation of the drainage system, the council determines that the system should be discontinued, that the
powers under this article should be revoked, and that provision for city drainage should be made by other revenues, the council may adopt an ordinance to that effect
after providing notice and a public hearing as provided by section 14.09.005.
(b) If the municipality discontinues a system under subsection (a), it may not adopt a system under this article for at least five years after the discontinuation.
(c) A discontinuation does not affect a written obligation incurred by the city for funding or for the purchase of equipment, materials, or labor for the drainage system
that is not then fully paid or otherwise discharged.
(d) A claim for damages based on an alleged failure of the drainage system that is filed with the city before the adoption of the ordinance discontinuing the drainage
system is not abated by the discontinuation.
(Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.060)
Secs. 14.09.061–14.09.090 Reserved

Division 4. Enforcement
Sec. 14.09.131 Delinquent payments
Any charge due hereunder which is not paid when due may be recovered in an action at law by the city. In addition to any other remedies or penalties provided at law or
in this article, failure of a user of the utility within the service area to pay the charges promptly when due shall subject such user to discontinuance of any utility services
provided by the city. The city manager or designee is hereby empowered to enforce this provision against delinquent users. The employees of the utility established in
accordance with this article shall have access, at all reasonable times, to any benefited properties served by the drainage utility for inspection or repair of the stormwater
facilities or for the enforcement of the provisions of this article. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 1, adopted 1/20/09; 2008 Code, sec. 13.09.131)
Sec. 14.09.132 Penalty
Each violation of this article shall be punished by a penalty of a fine in accordance with section 1.01.009 of this code. (Ordinance 09-003, sec. 2, adopted 1/20/09; 2008
Code, sec. 13.09.132; Ordinance adopting 2017 Code)
ARTICLE 14.10 TELECOMMUNICATIONS*
Division 1. Generally
Secs. 14.10.001–14.10.030 Reserved
Division 2. Use of Public Rights-of-Way†
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 213/349
Sec. 14.10.031 Purpose
The purpose of this division is to establish a competitively neutral policy for the use of the public rights-of-way for the provision of telecommunications services and
enable the city to:
(1) Establish a local policy with clear local guidelines, standards and time frames for the exercise of local authority with respect to telecommunications
providers using the public rights-of-way;
(2) Manage access to the public rights-of-way in order to minimize the congestion, inconvenience, visual impact and other adverse effects and the costs to
the citizens resulting from the placement of telecommunications facilities within the public rights-of-way;
(3) Obtain fair and reasonable compensation to the city for the private commercial use of the public right-of-way through the collection of nondiscriminatory
fees and charges;
(4) Promote competition among telecommunications service providers and encourage the universal availability of advanced telecommunications services
to all residents and businesses of the city;
(5) Conserve the limited physical capacity of the public rights-of-way held in public trust by the city;
(6) Assure that the city's current and ongoing costs of granting and regulating private access to and use of the public rights-of-way are fully paid by the
persons seeking such access and causing such costs;
(7) Assure that all telecommunications carriers providing facilities or services within the city comply with the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city;
(8) Assure that the city can continue to fairly and responsibly protect the public health, safety and welfare;
(9) Enable the city to discharge its public trust consistent with rapidly evolving federal and state regulatory policies, industry competition and technological
development; and
(10) Assure that the rights of current franchise holders are not unduly affected.
(1972 Code, ch. 35, sec. 1; 2008 Code, sec. 13.10.031)
Sec. 14.10.032 Definitions
Affiliate. A person who offers a telecommunications service and falls into one or more of the following categories:
(1) Each person having, directly or indirectly, a controlling interest in a provider;
(2) Each person in which a provider has, directly or indirectly, a controlling interest;
(3) Each officer, director, general partner, limited partner or shareholder holding an interest of fifteen percent (15%) or more, joint venturer or joint venture
partner, of a provider; and
(4) Each person, directly or indirectly, controlling, controlled by, or under common control with the provider;
provided that “affiliate” shall in no event mean any limited partner or shareholder holding an interest of less than fifteen percent (15%) of such provider, or any creditor of
such provider solely by virtue of its status as a creditor and which is not otherwise an affiliate by reason of owning a controlling interest in, being owned by, or being
under common ownership, common management, or common control with such provider.
Applicant. Any person who files an application with the city, under section 14.10.033, in order to obtain the necessary consent to place a telecommunications network
within the public rights-of-way of the city.
Cable Act. The Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 47 U.S.C. section 532 et seq., amended to January 1, 1997.
Cable operator. A person providing or offering to provide “cable service” within the city as that term is defined in the Cable Act.
Cable service. Shall have the same meaning provided by the Cable Act.
Certificated telecommunications utility. A telecommunications provider who is required to obtain or has a certificate of convenience and necessity or a certificate of
operating authority or a service provider certificate of operating authority by the Texas Public Utility Regulatory Act of 1995, as amended to January 1, 1996 (PURA), as
those terms are defined by PURA, as amended to January 1, 1996, to provide telecommunications services in the city.
City property. All real property owned by the city, other than public rights-of-way as that term is defined herein, and all other property held in a proprietary capacity by the
city, which are not subject to right-of-way licensing and franchising as provided in this division.
City requirements. All laws, rules, regulations, policies and directives of general application of the city, in effect at present or to be adopted in the future by the city
council.
Director. The director of the public works of the city or his or her designee, charged with the administration and enforcement of this division.
Director of public works. The director of the department of the city, or his or her designee, charged with the administration of the public rights-of-way.
Excess capacity. The volume or capacity in any existing or future duct, conduit, manhole, handhold or other utility facility within the public way that is or will be available
for use for additional telecommunications facilities.
Federal Communications Commission or FCC. The federal agency or its successor agency that is the regulatory authority over the telecommunications providers.
Gross revenue. Includes all revenues derived directly or indirectly by a provider from telecommunications services offered through a telecommunications network within
the city. Gross revenue does not include revenue uncollectible from customers (bad debt). By way of example, but without limitation, gross revenue includes:
(1) Revenue derived from cash sales, customer credit account sales, and property of any kind or nature or from any service whatsoever received or
accruing to the provider directly or indirectly arising from or attributable to the sale or exchange of telecommunications and/or network services by the
provider within the city;
(2) All telecommunications services revenues charged on a flat rate basis;
(3) All telecommunications services revenues charged on a usage sensitive or mileage basis;
(4) All revenues from connection or disconnection fees;
(5) All revenues from penalties, fees or charges to customers for checks returned from banks, net of bank costs paid;
(6) All revenue from local service;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 214/349
(7) All revenue from authorized rental or lease of conduit space;
(8) All revenue from charges for access to or from local and long distance networks;
(9) All revenue from authorized rentals or leases of any portion of the provider's telecommunications network, including, but not limited to, plant, facilities,
antenna towers or capacity leased to others;
(10) All revenues from enhanced data service;
(11) All interconnect and access and/or landline charges or revenues from wireless telecommunications entities, interexchange carriers and other
providers;
(12) All revenues derived from co-location connection fees;
(13) All revenues from subsidiary or affiliate entities or entities renting or leasing conduit space or any other part of the provider's network;
(14) Any fees collected from the customer, other than state sales taxes, but including all fees and charges collected pursuant to this division;
(15) Revenues from the lease or resale of lines or circuit paths to any affiliate or third parties; and
(16) All revenue from the sale, lease or access for or to network elements in the public rights-of-way (as contemplated by 47 C.F.R. part 51 et seq.).
Network element. A facility or equipment used in the provision of telecommunications service, such as the local loop, that is on or in the public rights-of-way.
Person. An individual, corporation, association, partnership, joint venture or other entity.
Public rights-of-way. The surface, the air space above the surface, and the area below the surface of any public street, highway, lane, path, alley, sidewalk, boulevard,
drive, bridge, tunnel, easement or similar property in which the city holds any property interest (fee title, easement or otherwise) or exercises any rights of management
or control and which, consistent with the purposes for which it was acquired or dedicated, may be used for the installation and maintenance of a telecommunications
network. This term specifically includes public rights-of-way of the state.
Public rights-of-way use agreement or PRWUA. A PRWUA is the municipal consent granted by the city council to providers to use public rights-of-way to place a
telecommunications network within the city as specified by the terms of such agreement and consistent with this division.
Public street crossing fee. Any fee charged for use of public rights-of-way for providers not having authority to use all of the city's rights-of-way, but serving customers
within the city, including but not limited to actual crossing of streets.
Public utility commission of the state or PUC. The state agency having jurisdiction over telecommunications providers.
Telecommunications network or network. All facilities of any kind placed in, on or above the public rights-of-way and used to provide telecommunications services.
Telecommunications provider or provider. A person, and any affiliate, who is required by this division to obtain a PRWUA, or who have been granted the right by a
PRWUA to place a telecommunications network within the city in accordance with this division.
Telecommunications services. All transmissions between or among points specified by the user, of information of the user's choosing (whether voice, video or data),
without change in the content of the information as sent and received, where such transmissions are accomplished by means of a telecommunications network.
Telecommunications services also include any ancillary or adjunct services which may be rendered in conjunction with transmissions described in the preceding
sentence. Telecommunications services are classified in the categories set forth in section 14.10.045. For levels 1, 2, and 3, these categories are intended to utilize
existing state law classifications and shall be interpreted to reflect any nonsubstantive modification of service categories implemented by the PUC or judicial decision.
“Telecommunications services” does not include cable service.
Utility infrastructure. All city electric utility distribution poles, transmission structures, ducts and all other city owned or operated transmission structures, distribution
conduit, building entry conduit, utility tunnels, manholes, vaults, radio towers, other radio equipment, fiber optic cable capacity and active communications capacity,
together with all appurtenant facilities.
Wholesale telecommunications services revenues. The revenue received by the provider from selling its telecommunications services at a wholesale rate to other
telecommunications carriers, as those terms are defined in and as required by sections 251 and 252 of the Federal Communications Act of 1934, as amended, the
Federal Code of Regulations, 47 C.F.R. section 51.601 et seq., and the PUC substantive rules, all as amended to January 1, 1997.
(1972 Code, ch. 35, sec. 2; 2008 Code, sec. 13.10.032)
Sec. 14.10.033 Application for use agreement
(a) Required. Any person proposing to place a telecommunications network within the public rights-of-way to provide telecommunications services, who does not have
a franchise agreement with the city on the date of the passage of this division, shall submit an application to the public works department. The application shall be in a
form prescribed by the director as generally described below, and shall describe all services the applicant wishes to provide, and outline the applicant's proposed
network and its impact on the public rights-of-way. The director may require the following information in the application:
(1) The identity of the applicant, including all affiliates of the applicant which may use in any manner the telecommunications network.
(2) A description of the telecommunications services that are or will be offered or provided by the applicant over its existing or proposed
telecommunications network.
(3) A description of the principal transmission medium that will be used by the applicant to offer or provide such telecommunications services.
(4) Preliminary engineering plans and specifications and a network map of the facilities to be located within the city, all in sufficient detail to identify:
(A) The location and route requested for the applicant's proposed telecommunications network.
(B) The location of all overhead and underground public utility, telecommunication, cable, water, sewer, drainage, curbs, pavements, sidewalks, and
other facilities in the public rights-of-way along the proposed route.
(C) The locations(s), if any, for interconnections with other telecommunications facilities or networks of other telecommunications providers.
(D) The specific trees, structures, improvements, facilities and obstructions, if any, that the applicant proposes to temporarily or permanently remove,
relocate, or cross under.
(5) If the applicant is proposing to install overhead facilities, evidence that surplus space is available for locating its telecommunications network on existing
utility poles along the proposed route, with evidence authorizing such use of the utility poles.
(6) If the applicant is proposing an underground installation in existing ducts or conduits within the public rights-of-way, information in sufficient detail to
identify:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 215/349
(A) That excess capacity is currently available in such ducts or conduits before installation of the applicant's telecommunications facilities and
evidence of authority for use of any such ducts or conduits;
(B) The excess capacity, if any, that will exist in such ducts or conduits after installation of the applicant's telecommunications facilities.
(7) If the applicant is proposing an underground installation within new ducts or conduits to be constructed within the public rights-of-way:
(A) The location proposed for the new ducts or conduits;
(B) The excess capacity that will exist in such ducts or conduits after installation of the applicant's telecommunications network.
(8) A preliminary construction schedule and completion dates.
(9) A preliminary traffic-control plan in accordance with the DOT Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices.
(10) Audited financial statements prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles demonstrating the applicant's financial ability to
construct, operate, maintain, relocate and remove the telecommunications network, prepared by an independent certified public accountant.
(11) Information in sufficient detail to establish the applicant's technical qualifications, experience and expertise regarding the telecommunications network
and services described in the application.
(12) Information to establish that the applicant will obtain all other governmental approvals and permits prior to construction and operation of the
telecommunications network and prior to offering or providing the telecommunications services.
(13) Whether the applicant intends to provide cable service or other video programming service, such as an open video system, as defined in the Cable
Act, together with sufficient information to determine whether such service is subject to cable franchising under the Cable Act.
(14) An accurate map showing the location of any existing telecommunications network in the city that the applicant intends to use or lease.
(15) A description of the services or facilities that the applicant will offer or make available to the city and other public, educational and governmental
institutions, if any, at rates differing from its customary charges and rates.
(16) A description of the applicant's access and line extension policies.
(17) The area or areas of the city the applicant desires to serve and a schedule for build-out to the entire city, if any.
(18) Information in sufficient detail that evidences that the applicant will provide or ensure a seamless interconnection with or through other
telecommunications service providers to the local emergency number district and evidence of compliance with chapters 771 and 772 of the Texas Health and
Safety Code on emergency communication, and the state public utility commission's Substantive Rules on Interconnection, particularly section 23.97(a), (d)
and (e), as amended.
(19) All fees, deposits or charges required pursuant to this division, or found elsewhere in the regulations of the city.
(20) Such other and further information as may be reasonably requested by the director.
(b) Authority of director. The director shall administer and enforce compliance with respect to all PRWUAs granted under this division. The director shall have the duty
to review applications submitted under this division and formulate recommendations to the city council regarding a PRWUA for the applicant. A recommendation to the
city council or a written notice of denial to the applicant shall be given within one hundred twenty (120) days after a completed application has been submitted to the
director; such time frame may be extended for good cause, with consent of the applicant. The director shall negotiate the terms of PRWUAs (consistent with and to the
extent not prescribed in this division) for adoption by the city council. The director shall consider the following:
(1) The capacity of the public rights-of-way to accommodate the applicant's proposed facilities.
(2) The capacity of the public rights-of-way to accommodate an additional telecommunications network if the PRWUA is granted.
(3) The damage or disruption, if any, of public or private facilities, improvements, service, travel or landscaping if the PRWUA is granted.
(4) The public interest in minimizing the cost and disruption of construction within the public rights-of-way.
(5) The service that the applicant will provide to the community and region.
(6) The effect, if any, on public health, safety and welfare if the PRWUA is granted.
(7) The availability of alternate routes and/or locations for the proposed facilities.
(8) Applicable federal and state telecommunications laws, regulations and policies.
(9) The financial and technical ability of the applicant.
(10) The legal authority of the applicant.
(11) Such other factors as may demonstrate that authorization to use the public rights-of-way will serve the community interest.
(c) City council action. All public rights-of-way use agreements approved by the city council under this division shall incorporate each applicable provision of this
division. All PRWUAs must be approved by the city council to be effective. The act of approval, consenting to, amending, denying or terminating PRWUAs is a legislative
function within the sound discretion of the city council. Any person who is denied a PRWUA or whose PRWUA is terminated must petition the city council for
reconsideration before seeking judicial remedies.
(d) Priority of usage. In case of conflict or interference between the facilities of different providers, the provider whose facilities were first permitted shall have priority
over a competing use of the public rights-of-way.
(e) No right to use city property or utility infrastructure granted by PRWUA. The grant of a PRWUA under this division shall not be construed to grant any attachment
rights or authorize the use of any city property or utility infrastructure in any manner without additional compliance by the provider with other applicable city requirements.
(f) Responsibility for adequacy of design. Review and approval by the city does not constitute a guarantee of sufficiency of the design of the telecommunications
network. The applicant retains full responsibility for the adequacy of the design of the telecommunications network.
(1972 Code, ch. 35, sec. 3; 2008 Code, sec. 13.10.033)
Sec. 14.10.034 Fees and charges; records
(a) Filing fee and administrative fee. To reimburse the city for its initial administrative costs in processing the application, each applicant shall submit a nonrefundable
application fee as provided in appendix A of this code as amended or revised by ordinance from time to time. Upon acceptance of a PRWUA granted by the city, a
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 216/349
provider shall pay an administrative fee as provided in appendix A of this code as amended or revised by ordinance from time to time, against which the application fee
will be credited. Such administrative fee is to defray the cost to the city in preparing and entering into the PRWUA.
(b) Public rights-of-way use fees and charges.
(1) Public rights-of-way use fee.
(A) Established; adjustment.
(i) The appropriate fair and reasonable compensation to the city for the use of its public rights-of-way on a city-wide basis is equal to 3% of the
gross revenues of the provider based on the “retail” sales revenue of its telecommunications services. Under FCC and PUC regulations adopted in
1996, pursuant to federal law, some providers are required to “unbundle” certain telecommunications services and to sell them at wholesale rates
to other telecommunications carriers for resale. In order for the city to recover appropriate compensation for the use of its public rights-of-way, a
fee equal to 4% of all wholesale telecommunications services revenues shall be paid to the city in accordance with this division and as part of the
public rights-of-way use fee, as stated below. (Such 4% fee on the wholesale telecommunications services revenue is based on an approximate
20% discount (discount rate) from the retail cost of the telecommunications services, such discount rate being set by the PUC from time to time.)
(ii) Such 4% fee on the wholesale telecommunications services revenue may be adjusted by the city from time to time, in the event the discount
rate of 20% is changed by the PUC or FCC, or other authorized entity, to ensure the city receives an amount substantially equal to, but not
exceeding, 3% of the retail value of gross revenue of the telecommunications services. Each PRWUA shall provide for such an adjustment.
(B) Rate. As provided in subsection (1)(A) of this section, because the use of the public rights-of-way on a city-wide basis is a valuable property right
for which reasonable compensation is due the city, each provider, except as provided in subsections (b)(2) and (3), shall pay the city an annual rental
fee (public rights-of-way use fee) equal to:
(i) 3% of the provider's or other affiliate's gross revenue obtained from the provision of telecommunications services using the
telecommunications network; and
(ii) 4% of the provider's wholesale telecommunications services revenue obtained from other telecommunications carriers, including but not
limited to certificated telecommunications utilities, using the telecommunications network, subject to adjustment in accordance with subsection (A)
above and credits in accordance with subsection (C) below.
(C) Credit. In no event shall the fee on wholesale telecommunications service revenue exceed 3% of the actual retail revenue of the
telecommunications services sold by the other telecommunications carriers(s). Upon sufficient documentation and information furnished to the city by
the provider, as may be reasonably required by the city, the provider will be entitled to a credit on the next public rights-of-way use fee payment to the
extent the fee payment on wholesale revenue exceeds 3% of the actual retail revenue. For the purposes of this section, wholesale rates and retail rates
for telecommunications services shall have the same meaning as in the Communications Act of 1934, as amended by the Telecommunications Act of
1996, section 251(c)(4), or in section 252(d)(3), or as provided in the PUC Substantive Rules, as amended to January 1, 1997.
(D) Quarterly payment. Providers shall remit the public rights-of-way use fee to the city on a quarterly basis, prorated as applicable (quarterly
payment). Each quarterly payment shall be made by wire transfer to the account designated by the director, and this payment shall be due on the fortyfifth
(45th) day following the close of each calendar quarter for which the payment is calculated (due date).
(E) Quarterly report. In order for the city to determine that the gross revenue received by the provider is reported correctly, the provider shall agree
that, on the same date that each quarterly payment is made, as provided in this section, it will file with the city secretary a sworn copy of a report, in a
form to be prescribed and acceptable to the director, which is in sufficient detail to itemize revenues from each category of the telecommunications
services to determine the accuracy of the quarterly payment.
(F) Late fees. In the event a quarterly payment is made after noon on the due date, the provider shall pay a late payment fee of the greater of:
(i) $100.00; or
(ii) Simple interest at a ten percent (10%) annual percentage rate of the total amount past due.
(2) Public street crossing fee.
(A) Any provider which has a specific route for its telecommunications network and which does not have authority to use all of the city's public rightsof-
way in its PRWUA, but does serve customers or other providers within the city, shall pay the city an annual public street crossing fee of:
(i) $1.35 per linear foot for each diameter inch or fraction thereof of underground conduit or wire and for each 0.250 diameter inch or less of
aerial wire that is in the public rights-of-way per annum; and
(ii) $2,000.00 for one street crossing and $6.00 for every street crossing thereafter.
(B) This fee shall be due on July 15 of every year of the PRWUA, prorated as applicable. A report as required by the director shall be provided with
each annual payment showing the calculation of the payment, including the length of the network, outside diameter of the wire, outside diameter of the
conduit, and whether it is overhead or underground, as applicable, and number and name of each street crossing.
(C) This fee is to compensate the city for the reasonable rental value of the public rights-of-way used by the provider, and to recover the
administrative cost in monitoring and enforcing the provisions of this division and of the PRWUA. Each PRWUA shall provide that such fee may be
adjusted once every three (3) years to properly reflect the reasonable rental value of the public rights-of-way and administrative cost to the city.
(3) Administrative public right-of-way use charge.
(A) Any provider which uses a telecommunications network within the city but which serves no customers within the city other than itself shall pay an
annual administrative public right-of-way use charge of:
(i) $1.50 per linear foot for each diameter inch or fraction thereof of underground conduit or wire and for each 0.250 diameter inch or less of
aerial wire that is in the public rights-of-way per annum; and
(ii) $2,000.00 for one street crossing and $6.00 for every street crossing thereafter.
(B) This charge shall be due on July 15 of every year of the PRWUA, after the first 12 months of the PRWUA, prorated as applicable. A report as
required by the director shall be provided with each annual payment showing the calculation of the payment, including the length of the network, outside
diameter of the wire, outside diameter of the conduit and whether it is overhead or underground, as applicable, and number and name of each street
crossing.
(C) This charge is to recover the city's administrative and regulatory cost for the monitoring and enforcing of the provisions of this division and the
PRWUA. Each PRWUA shall provide that such administrative charge may be adjusted once every three (3) years to fully reimburse the city for its
administrative cost.
(c) Default. Notwithstanding any other provision in this division, in the event that full and proper payments due the city under this division or the PRWUA have not
been made by a provider within twenty (20) days after the due date, an event of default shall have occurred, in which case the city may terminate the PRWUA as set
forth in this division or in the PRWUA.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 217/349
(d) No release of other claims. No acceptance of any payment shall be construed as a release of, or an accord or satisfaction of, any claim that the city might have for
further or additional sums payable under the terms of this division or a PRWUA, or for any other performance or obligations of a provider.
(e) Permit and inspection charges. All permit and inspection charges related to a provider's construction and maintenance in the public rights-of-way shall be paid by
the provider as established by the director.
(f) Adjustments. Every PRWUA granted under this division shall include a clause specifying that the level of compensation received by the city for public rights-of-way
usage shall be adjusted upward to be equal to that of any other Texas city in which such provider offers telecommunications services.
(g) Other city fees, taxes and charges. Payments of compensation made by a provider to the city pursuant to this division or a PRWUA shall be considered in addition
to, and exclusive of, any and all authorized taxes, business license fees, other fees, or other levies or assessments presently in effect, or subsequently adopted, to the
extent provided under applicable law.
(h) Nonmonetary consideration. To the fullest extent allowed by law, the city may require nonmonetary consideration from each provider. To the extent not expressly
provided by applicable law, the provider may agree to furnish to the city nonmonetary consideration in the form of network capacity, conduit or other infrastructure. This
nonmonetary consideration will be negotiated with each provider, taking into account the unique characteristics of each, shall be competitively neutral, and shall not
discriminate in favor of or against any provider with respect to total compensation. Such nonmonetary compensation may be used as a credit or an offset against the
monetary consideration, as may be mutually agreed to by the city and the provider in the PRWUA.
(i) Books and records.
(1) Providers shall keep complete and accurate books of accounts and records of their business and operations pursuant to any PRWUA granted
hereunder in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles; however, providers shall keep their books of account and records in such a way that
identification of all revenues by type of telecommunications service within the city is available. If required by the FCC, the PUC or the state comptroller for
sales tax purposes, providers may use the systems of accounts and the forms of books, accounts, records, and memoranda prescribed by those entities;
provided, however, that the director may require the keeping of additional records or accounts which are reasonably necessary for purposes of identifying,
accounting for, and reporting gross revenue and uncollectibles for purposes of this division.
(2) Upon written request from the director, providers shall report to the city such other information as the director may reasonably require to ensure correct
payments to the city are made and shall comply with the city's reasonable determination of forms for reports, the time for reports, the frequency with which
any reports are to be made, and if reports are to be made under oath. Such reports may include a report prepared by an independent certified public
accountant.
(3) Providers shall promptly make available to the city or a city designated representative, upon the director's reasonable written request, their books and
records to examine, audit, review and/or obtain copies of the papers, books, accounts, documents, maps, plans and other records of providers pertaining to
PRWUAs granted under this division to ensure proper payments are made to the city. Providers shall fully cooperate in making available their records and
otherwise assisting in these activities.
(4) The director may, at any time, make inquiries pertaining to a provider's performance of the terms and conditions of a PRWUA. Providers shall respond
to such inquiries on a timely basis.
(5) The city will maintain confidentiality of information provided by providers to the extent permitted by law when providers have notified the city in writing of
the confidential nature of the information. The city will furnish providers with copies of any attorney general opinion request under the Open Records Act
which pertains to such information.
(6) (A) Without any prior request, providers shall promptly and timely furnish the city with written notice of all petitions, applications,
communications and reports submitted by providers to the FCC, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the PUC, or their successor agencies,
relating to any matters affecting the use of city public rights-of-way and/or the telecommunications services authorized pursuant to a PRWUA granted
under this division. Upon written request from the director, providers shall promptly and timely furnish the city with copies of all such documents, which
shall be no later than 10 business days from the date of the written request.
(B) Without limiting the above subsection, the provider shall promptly furnish to the city a copy of the initial registration, and any updated registrations,
required by PUC Substantive Rules section 23.61(i), as amended, and a copy of the initial, [and] any update of the annual informational filing required
by PUC Substantive Rules section 23.61(j), as amended.
(j) City's right to audit.
(1) The city reserves the right to review and audit the provider's books and records, if the city deems it necessary in order to determine if the appropriate
amount has been paid to the city. If such audit discovers an underpayment due the city that exceeds five percent (5%) of the total amount paid for any
quarterly or annual reporting period, as applicable, then the provider shall promptly reimburse the city for the actual and reasonable cost of such an audit. The
provider shall also pay the city all actual amounts of the underpayments as determined by the audit.
(2) If an audit or other research discovers that fees or charges have been either underpaid or not paid for any period, in addition to all other remedies under
this division under the PRWUA and at law, the city also may seek full recovery of the underpaid or nonpaid fees or charges, plus interest at a 10% annual
percentage rate, from the original due date.
(1972 Code, ch. 35, sec. 4; Ordinance adopting 2008 Code; 2008 Code, sec. 13.10.034; Ordinance adopting 2017 Code)
Sec. 14.10.035 Transfer of use agreement
(a) No PRWUA granted under this division, the assets held by providers for use under such PRWUA which are in the public rights-of-way, or any rights or privileges of
providers under a PRWUA, either separately or collectively, shall be sold, resold, assigned, transferred or conveyed by providers under a PRWUA, either separately or
collectively, shall be sold, resold, assigned, transferred or conveyed by providers [sic] to any other person without the prior written consent of the city by ordinance or
resolution. Such approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. Should the provider sell, assign, transfer, convey or otherwise dispose of any of its rights or interests under
the PRWUA, including such provider's telecommunications network, or attempt to do so, without the city's prior consent, the city may revoke the PRWUA for default, in
which event all rights and interest of the provider shall cease.
(b) Any transfer in violation of this section shall be null and void and unenforceable. Any change of control of a provider shall constitute a transfer under this section.
(c) There shall be a rebuttable presumption of a change of control of a provider upon a change of 15% or greater in the ownership of such provider. Such a change in
control shall be deemed a transfer which requires consent of the city.
(d) A mortgage or other pledge of assets to a bank or lending institution in a bona fide lending transaction shall not be considered an assignment or transfer.
(e) Every PRWUA granted under this division shall specify that any transfer or other disposition of rights which has the effect of circumventing payment of required
PRWUA fees and/or evasion of payment of such fees by noncollection or nonreporting of revenues derived from telecommunications services, bartering or any other
means which evade the actual collection of revenues for business pursued by a provider is prohibited.
(1972 Code, ch. 35, sec. 5; 2008 Code, sec. 13.10.035)
Sec. 14.10.036 Obligations of providers regarding public rights-of-way
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 218/349
(a) Compliance with law. Providers are explicitly subject to the police powers of the city, and other governmental powers, and the city's rights as a property owner
under state and federal laws. All work done by providers in connection with the construction, expansion, reconstruction, maintenance or repair of their facilities in the
public rights-of-way shall be subject to and governed by all city requirements, and applicable federal and state rules and regulations. Providers shall place or relocate
certain facilities underground when required by applicable city requirements. For this section, the term “provider” shall also mean a person who controls or manages
physical transmission facilities, and all appurtenant equipment, installed in the public rights-of-way.
(b) Duty to furnish information to city. Upon request, providers shall provide the city timely information as to all matters in connection with or affecting the construction,
reconstruction, removal, maintenance, operation and repair of facilities performed by providers in the public rights-of-way.
(c) Construction work regulation, maintenance and underground conduit use.
(1) All excavations and other construction in the public rights-of-way shall be performed in accordance with all applicable city requirements, including the
obligation to use trenchless technology whenever possible. Furthermore, all such construction shall be undertaken so as to minimize interference with the use
of public and private property and in accordance with any direction given by the city under the police and regulatory powers of the city.
(2) Providers may be required by the city to attach portions of their facilities to poles or duct trench space maintained by any other person or entity
authorized by the city to the extent reasonable. A provider shall not be required to attach its facilities to the poles or duct trench space of any other person or
entity authorized by the city if it can be shown to the city's satisfaction that such provider shall be subjected thereby to increased risks of interruption to its
service or to increased liability for accidents, or unreasonable delay in construction or availability of service, or if the facilities of such other person or entity
are not of the character, design and construction required by or are not being maintained in accordance with current practice, or are not available to the
provider on reasonable terms, including, without limitation, a reasonable fee.
(3) In furtherance of the public interest in safety, health and public welfare and to facilitate the safe management of public rights-of-way, the construction,
expansion, reconstruction, excavation, use, maintenance and operation of the provider's telecommunications network and property shall be subject to all
generally applicable city requirements as determined by the director or designee.
(4) In addition to any other city requirements, thirty (30) days prior to the commencement of construction which involves any alteration to the surface or the
subsurface of the public rights-of-way, to the extent generally required, providers shall furnish the director (or such other officials as the city may designate
from time to time) with construction plans and maps showing the routing of any new construction and construction plans. Providers shall not commence
construction until the plans and drawings have been approved in writing by the director. Such approval shall not be unreasonably withheld or delayed.
(5) Upon request by written notice of the city, providers shall promptly remove and abate any facility that is declared an emergency by the city. Providers
and the city shall cooperate to the extent possible to assure continuity of service during the removal. If any provider, after notice, fails or refuses to act, the
city may remove or abate the same, at the sole cost and expense of such provider, which shall be promptly paid to the city, all without compensation or
liability for damages to the provider.
(6) Upon completion of initial or any subsequent construction work, providers shall promptly restore the public rights-of-way in accordance with applicable
city requirements. Providers given notice under this section may excavate only for the construction, installation, expansion, repair, removal, and maintenance
of all or a portion of its telecommunications network.
(7) Except in an emergency, a provider shall not excavate any pavement in any public alley or street or significant amounts of any unpaved public right-ofway
without first complying with all applicable city requirements.
(8) Within one hundred twenty (120) days of completion of each segment of the provider's telecommunications network, each provider shall supply the city
with a complete set of “as built” drawings for that segment in a format to be prescribed by director. Providers shall provide the city a compete set of “as built”
drawings annually, and at no cost to the city, incorporating any changes to the provider's telecommunications network in the public rights-of-way, in a format
to be prescribed by the director. Providers shall also obtain the city's approval before any relocation of the provider's telecommunications network in the public
rights-of-way. Such approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. In addition, a provider shall provide annually to the city a map of its telecommunications
network.
(9) Providers shall participate in any local utility coordination council, currently existing or as may be established, meetings and coordinate all new
construction with same. The provider's telecommunications network shall bear identification marks, as may be established by such council, to the extent such
telecommunications networks are installed after the council establishes such identification marks.
(d) Work by others, construction by abutting owners and alterations to conform with public improvements.
(1) The city reserves the right to lay and permit to be laid sewer, gas, water, and other pipelines or cables and conduits, and to do and permit to be done
any underground and overhead work, and any attachment, restructuring or changes in aerial facilities, that may be deemed necessary or proper by the city,
in, across, along, over or under any public street, alley or right-of-way occupied by providers, and to change any curb or sidewalk or the grade of any street.
In permitting such work to be done, the city shall not be liable to providers for any damages not directly caused by the willful misconduct or gross negligence
of the city; provided, however, that nothing herein shall relieve any other person or entity, including any contractor, subcontractor, or agent, from liability for
damage to providers' facilities.
(2) In the event that, during the term of the PRWUA, the city authorizes abutting landowners to occupy space under the surface of any public street, alley,
or right-of-way, such grant to an abutting landowner shall be subject to the rights herein granted to providers. In the event that the city shall close or abandon
any public right-of-way which contains any portion of providers' facilities, any conveyance of land contained in such closed or abandoned public right-of-way
shall be subject to the rights herein granted.
(3) During the term of all PRWUAs, providers shall be liable for the acts or omissions of any entity used by providers (including an affiliate) when such
entity is involved directly or indirectly in the construction and installation of providers' facilities, to the same extent as if the acts or omissions of such entity
were the acts or omissions of a provider.
(4) Relocation or removal of facilities. Within thirty (30) days following written notice from the city, the providers shall, at their expense, temporarily or
permanently remove, relocate, change or alter the position of any of their facilities or telecommunications network that are in the public rights-of-way
whenever the city shall have determined that such removal, relocation, change or alteration is reasonably necessary for:
(A) The construction, repair, maintenance or installation of any city or other public improvement in or upon the public rights-of-way; or
(B) The operations of the city or other governmental entity in or upon the public rights-of-way.
(1972 Code, ch. 35, sec. 6; 2008 Code, sec. 13.10.036)
Sec. 14.10.037 Insurance requirements
(a) Providers shall obtain and maintain in full force and effect, throughout the term of a PRWUA granted under this division, insurance with an insurance company
licensed to do business in the state and acceptable to the city as determined by its representative. All companies will be required to be rated A-VI or better by A.M. Best
or A or better by Standard and Poors. Providers shall furnish the city with proof of such insurance so required at the time of filing the acceptance of a PRWUA, and to
reasonably adjust insurance coverage and their limits when deemed necessary and prudent by the city's risk manager, based upon changes in statutory law, court
decisions, or the claims history of the industry or the provider.
(b) Subject to the provider's right to maintain reasonable deductibles in such amounts as are approved by the city's risk manager, providers shall obtain and maintain
in full force and effect for the duration of any PRWUA, at the provider's sole expense, insurance coverage in the following type and minimum amounts:
